contentList.content: You have set aside even your own purity to right wrongs and deliver justice to those who have committed the most grievous sins.
A promise made so deeply that it becomes divine in itself flows through a paladin, burning bright enough to inspire allies and smite foes.
You have broken your sacred Oath in pursuit of power and ambition. Only darkness remains to fuel you now.

Shadowheart willingly undertook a ritual to remove her memories in order to protect the secrets of her fellow Shar worshippers. Loss and pain are sacred to her, but her faith is now being tested like never before.
Clerics are representatives of the gods they worship, wielding potent divine magic for good or ill.
You gain [3] Level [4] spell slot(s), which are restored on a <LSTag Tooltip="LongRest">Long Rest</LSTag>.
You gain [3] level [4] spell slot(s), which are restored on a <LSTag Tooltip="LongRest">Long Rest</LSTag>.

You gain the ability to channel divine energy, starting with two effects: Turn Undead and an effect determined by your domain. Replenished by <LSTag Tooltip="ShortRest">Short</LSTag> or <LSTag Tooltip="LongRest">Long Rest</LSTag>.
A domain shared by wicked, chaotic, and mischievous deities, those who channel Trickery specialise in deception and illusion magic.
The Trickery Domain gives you access to certain spells. These are <LSTag Tooltip="AlwaysPrepared">Always Prepared</LSTag>.
Fuelled by the Oath you swore to uphold justice and righteousness, you are a beacon of hope in dark times.
Gain an additional <LSTag Type="ActionResource" Tooltip="LayOnHandsCharge">Lay on Hands Charge</LSTag> to heal yourself or your allies.
Your <LSTag Tooltip="MovementSpeed">movement speed</LSTag> increases by [1] while not wearing Heavy Armour.
Spells granted to you by the sacred power of your oath. These are <LSTag Tooltip="AlwaysPrepared">Always Prepared</LSTag>.
Clerics are representatives of the gods they worship, wielding potent divine magic for good or ill.
You wield the unorthodox divine tools of deceit and illusion in worship of your chosen deity.

Nightbringers are Priests and Priestess who worship Shar, Singer of Eternal Night.
Unlike most other clerics, their divine magic is drained from Darkness and not from Light. Their magic is also refering as Unholy Power, Shadow Weave or Netheril-Remnant Magic.
Nightbringers are priestess who worship Shar, Singer of Eternal Night. Unlike most others cleric, their power comes from Shar's divine magic, drained from Darkness and not from Light.
This creature deals an additional [1] when attacking from the shadows.
This creature can see through magical and non-magical darkness, and cannot be <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BLINDED">Blinded</LSTag>.
You can see normally in darkness, both magical and non-magical, to a distance of [1].
You gain [3] level [4] spell slot(s), which are restored on a <LSTag Tooltip="LongRest">Long Rest</LSTag>.
You gain [3] Level [4] spell slot(s), which are restored on a <LSTag Tooltip="LongRest">Long Rest</LSTag>.
The target gains a +1d4 bonus to <LSTag Tooltip="AbilityCheck">Ability Checks</LSTag>.
Putrefy a creature with the necrotic energy filling your hands.
The target gains a +1d4 bonus to <LSTag Tooltip="AbilityCheck">Ability Checks</LSTag>.
Encase yourself with a shimmering field of magic that increases your <LSTag Tooltip="ArmourClass">Armour Class</LSTag> by 2.
Encase yourself with a shimmering field of magic that increases your <LSTag Tooltip="ArmourClass">Armour Class</LSTag> by 2.
Encase yourself with a shimmering field of magic that increases your <LSTag Tooltip="ArmourClass">Armour Class</LSTag> by 2.
Encase yourself with a shimmering field of magic that increases your <LSTag Tooltip="ArmourClass">Armour Class</LSTag> by 2.
The most common face in Faerûn, humans are known for their tenacity, creativity, and endless capacity for growth.

Driven to the Underdark, most drow have adopted a ruthless pragmatism. While the Lolth-sworn delight in the goddess' evil tenets, the Seldarine reject Her attempt to overthrow the leader of the elven pantheon.
With ethereal countenances and long lifespans, elves are at home with nature's power, flourishing in light and dark alike.
The most common face in Faerûn, humans are known for their tenacity, creativity, and endless capacity for growth.

Raised by Lolth's cult in the city of Menzoberranzan, these drow embody the virtues of their corrupt and merciless goddess. Lolth marks Her followers with bright red eyes so those in the Underdark will learn to fear them on sight.
Seldarine drow can be found seeking allies from all over Faerûn, aiming to settle their conflict with Lolth - and each other - by any means necessary.
As durable and unyielding as their homes of stone, dwarves are some of the finest warriors, miners, and smiths of Faerûn.
Once enslaved by the eldritch mind flayers, duergar adapted to freedom with harsh practicality. Their cold demeanours and gift of stealth are well-known throughout the Underdark.
Curious, ambitious, and versatile, half-elves are welcome everywhere, but struggle without a community to call their own.
Small, clever, and energetic, gnomes use their long lives to explore Faerûn's brightest corners and darkest depths.
Small yet capable, halflings prefer the comforts of home and hearth - but their natural luck and dexterity makes them fine adventurers.
Descended from devils of the Nine Hells, tieflings face constant suspicion in Faerûn. Thankfully, their arcane abilities make them natural survivors.

With a ruthlessness borne from mind flayer enslavement, githyanki ride the Astral Sea atop red dragons, bringing their silver swords and psionic might to bear against any trace of the illithid menace.
A collection of bipedal races, ranging from humans, elves, and halflings to goblins, gnolls, and kobolds.

Shar's influence on the Underdark has always been important. The Shadow Weave took its root deep in it, and many creatures were sucked into the remnants of powerful black magic rituals across the years.
Voidborns are mortal creatures not native to the Shadowfell, but who have been willingly or unwillingly harmed by Netheril or Shadow derivated magic.
Such unhealing wounds act as conduits between Voidborns and the Dark Lady, it infuse theim with Unholy powers, but bind theim to serve Shar in death.
Any clerics can become Dark Knight, should they sworn the Unholy Oath of Shar. Beware Champion, the Unholy Oath of Shar cannot be broke and condemn you to serve Shar in death for eternity.
Humans touched by dark magics, most of the time remnants of Netheril magic.
You can see in the dark up to [1].
This creature can see through magical and non-magical darkness, and cannot be <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BLINDED">Blinded</LSTag>.
This creature can see through magical and non-magical darkness, and cannot be <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BLINDED">Blinded</LSTag>.
You can see normally in darkness, both magical and non-magical, to a distance of [1].
As durable and unyielding as their homes of stone, dwarves are some of the finest warriors, miners, and smiths of Faerûn.

During the Spellplague, a cataclysmic attempt of Cyric and Shar to murder the goddess of all magics Mystra, many Duergar turned to Asmodee as a reference lawful evil deity to worship. Sadly, the later took advantage of the surrounding chaos to perform an ancient infernal ritual, draining the souls of thousands so he could consume the lesser deity Azuth and ascend Lord of the Nine Hells. Draining its power from the very essence of the Shadow Weave, this ritual created many Voidborns along the way.
Once enslaved by the eldritch mind flayers, duergar adapted to freedom with harsh practicality. Their cold demeanours and gift of stealth are well-known throughout the Underdark.
Curious, ambitious, and versatile, half-elves are welcome everywhere, but struggle without a community to call their own.

Even in the most faithful churchs of Lolth, a lot of Drows turned against their tyrannical goddess in favor of Shar, attracted by the warming embrace of the pragmatic greated deity of Darkness.
While Half-drow may sometimes inherit a few magical gifts, they aren't usually raised in the Underdark.
Small, clever, and energetic, gnomes use their long lives to explore Faerûn's brightest corners and darkest depths.

In the later 14th century, Grymforge served as headquarters for Thorm Dark Justiciars. Priestess Sister Ansar converted the gnome Silouv Yali (probably via torture) to the Sharran faith, some of his follower were directly touch by the unholy rituals, suffering necrotic wounds. They became Voidborns.
More guarded than their surface cousins, deep gnomes survive in the Underdark with darkvision and skilful stealth.
Descended from devils of the Nine Hells, tieflings face constant suspicion in Faerûn. Thankfully, their arcane abilities make them natural survivors.

Bound to Nessus, the deepest layer of the Hells, these tieflings inherited the ability to wield fire and darkness from the archdevil Asmodeus' infernal bloodline.
« He forgot what it was to be human. What it was to not wear the god's mantle. He forgot what it was to crave power. And so he was not there when her rivals came for his queen. Down, down, the wizard fell, from heights of the heavens to the depths of the Hells, the fabric of the very planes tearing as he passed. And perhaps, then, it was a fitting punishment, for the wizard who forgot what it was to want, that he landed broken at the feet of one who was nothing but want incarnate. He remembers now, too late, what it means, the perils and the potentials. » Azuth, ending his tale devoured by the Nine Hells primal incarnation.
A proud race that values clan and skills above all else. Once enslaved by dragons, they strive to be self-sufficient, not wanting to be beholden to anyone, not even the gods.

Dragons are the incarnation of primal energy flows and so are Dragonborns. As Light and Darkness stands as primal energies, Dragonborns attune to these magics naturally. While extremely receptive to divine powers, their control over magic is eratic. This very trait make theim fantastical conduits for gods schemes and many Dragonborn found inner peace in the Martial Oaths ways.
Because of this primal arcanic affinity they have, when Black Dragonborn enter in contact with pure Shadow Weave, they may turns into complex magical entities called Dragonshade. These are the only entities capable of melting Chaos and Shadow primal energies to create Shadowflames.

Any clerics can become Dark Knight, should they sworn the Unholy Oath of Shar.
Beware Champion, the Unholy Oath of Shar cannot be broke and condemn you to serve Shar in death for eternity.
Distract your enemies with an illusion. Within [1] of the illusion, <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Rolls</LSTag> have <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> for you and your allies.
Both the attacker and the creature must be within [1] of the illusion.
Grant another creature <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> on Stealth <LSTag Tooltip="AbilityCheck">Checks</LSTag>.

Shar has many enemies. First, there are the clerics of Selûne, then come the worshipers of other deities, and finally, the Oathsworn and Voidborns who dare to defy their fates. Yet among all her foes, none capture Shar's attention more than the Nightbringers who oppose her—their defiance a personal affront to the Mistress of Night.

Shar have many enemis. First you have Selûne clerics, then come other deities worshipers et finally Oathsworns and Voidborns trying to escape their fate.

In fact, better is to list whose not Enemy of Shar. It is restraint to members of Sharran Church, a handful of races worshipping related deities and oathsworn Knights.
Once enslaved by the eldritch mind flayers, duergar adapted to freedom with harsh practicality. Their cold demeanours and gift of stealth are well-known throughout the Underdark.
Small, clever, and energetic, gnomes use their long lives to explore Faerûn's brightest corners and darkest depths.
As durable and unyielding as their homes of stone, dwarves are some of the finest warriors, miners, and smiths of Faerûn.
These dwarves are known for their confidence and keen intuition. The culture of their Deep Kingdom values family, ritual, and fine craftsmanship.
Great losses in ancient wars against goblins and orcs have led these dwarves to adopt a cynical mindset, but they will endure anything to restore their ancestral homelands.

Voidborns are mortal creatures not native to the Shadowfell, but who have been willingly or unwillingly harmed by Netheril or Shadow derivated magic. Such unhealing wounds act as conduits between Voidborns and the Dark Lady, it infuse theim with Unholy powers, but bind theim to serve Shar in death.

Bhaal is the notorious god of murder, reborn after each of his descendants were viciously slain. He has a tenuous alliance with Myrkul and Bane, the three having attained divinity in a bargain with Jergal.
A collection of bipedal races, ranging from humans, elves, and halflings to goblins, gnolls, and kobolds.
The most common face in Faerûn, humans are known for their tenacity, creativity, and endless capacity for growth.
With ethereal countenances and long lifespans, elves are at home with nature's power, flourishing in light and dark alike.
Heirs of the mystical Feywild, high elves value magic in all its forms, and even those who do not study spellcraft can manipulate the Weave.
These elves spend their reclusive lives in Faerûn's forests. Decades of training in archery and camouflage are enhanced by an otherworldly swiftness.

Driven to the Underdark, most drow have adopted a ruthless pragmatism. While the Lolth-sworn delight in the goddess' evil tenets, the Seldarine reject Her attempt to overthrow the leader of the elven pantheon.

Raised by Lolth's cult in the city of Menzoberranzan, these drow embody the virtues of their corrupt and merciless goddess. Lolth marks Her followers with bright red eyes so those in the Underdark will learn to fear them on sight.
Seldarine drow can be found seeking allies from all over Faerûn, aiming to settle their conflict with Lolth - and each other - by any means necessary.
As durable and unyielding as their homes of stone, dwarves are some of the finest warriors, miners, and smiths of Faerûn.
These dwarves are known for their confidence and keen intuition. The culture of their Deep Kingdom values family, ritual, and fine craftsmanship.
Great losses in ancient wars against goblins and orcs have led these dwarves to adopt a cynical mindset, but they will endure anything to restore their ancestral homelands.
Once enslaved by the eldritch mind flayers, duergar adapted to freedom with harsh practicality. Their cold demeanours and gift of stealth are well-known throughout the Underdark.
Curious, ambitious, and versatile, half-elves are welcome everywhere, but struggle without a community to call their own.
A touch of the Feywild remains in half-elves with this bloodline, and even those untrained in magic possess a hint of wild power.
Like their wood elf parent, these half-elves have a quickened stride and an eye for stealth. Yet many break away from isolation in Faerûn's forests to explore the rest of the Realms.
Most half-drow result from liaisons between Seldarine drow and surfacers. While half-drow inherited a few magical gifts, they aren't usually raised in the Underdark.
Small, clever, and energetic, gnomes use their long lives to explore Faerûn's brightest corners and darkest depths.
The most commonly seen gnomes on Faerûn's surface, rock gnomes are named as such for their hardiness and affinity for metal.
More guarded than their surface cousins, deep gnomes survive in the Underdark with darkvision and skilful stealth.
Even smaller than their cousins and twice as reclusive, forest gnomes are a rare sight in Faerûn. They master magic and craftsmanship in their distant, idyllic groves.
Small yet capable, halflings prefer the comforts of home and hearth - but their natural luck and dexterity makes them fine adventurers.
Stealthy but social, these halflings travel all over Faerûn to make names for themselves.
Legend has it that dwarven blood gave stronghearts their hardiness. Resistant to poison and wellsprings of endurance, these halflings easily hold their own.
Descended from devils of the Nine Hells, tieflings face constant suspicion in Faerûn. Thankfully, their arcane abilities make them natural survivors.
Bound to Nessus, the deepest layer of the Hells, these tieflings inherited the ability to wield fire and darkness from the archdevil Asmodeus' infernal bloodline.
Descended from the archdevil Mephistopheles, these tieflings are gifted with a particular affinity for arcane magic.
Tieflings from Zariel's bloodline are empowered with martial strength, and can channel searing flame to punish their enemies.

With a ruthlessness borne from mind flayer enslavement, githyanki ride the Astral Sea atop red dragons, bringing their silver swords and psionic might to bear against any trace of the illithid menace.
Tieflings from Zariel's bloodline are empowered with martial strength, and can channel searing flame to punish their enemies.
Even a generation apart, forest blood breeds true. These half-elves retain their parent's gift for speed, but tend to wander rather than staying in hidden enclaves.
You're a champion of the common people, challenging tyrants and monsters to protect the helpless. Saving people in imminent danger will make your legend grow.
Ilmater is the god of suffering and endurance. His clerics defend the oppressed and take on the burdens of others, leading to a reputation as martyrs among common folk.
Being raised in the Underdark casts a cruel shadow on one's view of the world, even up on the surface.
Tempus is the god of war. His clerics welcome conflict through force of arms, but only abide honourable combat and courageous action.
Durable and unyielding as their homes of stone, dwarves are some of the finest warriors, miners, and smiths of Faerûn.
Raised in one of the distant and hostile regions of Faerûn, an outlander can survive in the outdoors with very little.
Reclusive and wise, wood elves are primarily found in the forests of Faerûn. Rigorous training makes them masters of archery and camouflage, enhanced by an otherworldly swiftness.
Someone who's survived breaking the law time and again. Intimidation and connections are their best protection.
With an ethereal countenance and long lifespans, elves are at home with nature and its power. Flourishing in light and darkness alike, an elf can be beautiful and terrifying in equal measure.
A tome of necromancy has seared strange, profane glyphs into your mind, but you cannot understand them.
Tempus is the god of war, and his paladins are honourable but fearsome foes. They keep the world in balance with force of arms and unwavering courage.
The most common face to see in Faerûn, humans often face stiff competition from long-lived races, but hold their own with tenacity, creativity, and an endless capacity for growth.
Myrkul is the god of death and decay. Paladins who worship him are rare, but those who do are harbingers of a horrific demise for all those around them.
You are a female of one of the races; you are perceived as female by those that encounter you.
You are a male of one of the races; you are perceived as male by those that encounter you.
While more guarded than surface gnomes, deep gnomes are known for their loyalty and cunning. Their darkvision and training in stealth keep them alive in the hostile Underdark.
Mystra is the goddess of all magic. Her paladins guard magical lore and artefacts with their lives, ensuring their goddess' power is preserved from one generation to the next.

Raised in one of Lolth's massive cults spread throughout the Underdark, these drow extol the virtues of their corrupt and merciless goddess, seeking to bring all other drow under her sway. Lolth marks her followers with vivid red eyes, in hope every race in Faerûn will learn to fear the very sight of them.
Clerics channel the power of the gods they worship, wielding potent magic and acting as representatives of divine authority.
Masters of tactics and combat, fighters are the product of rigorous and relentless training. They move in armour like a second skin, and can wield any weapon with unmatched skill.

You have spent your life in service to a temple, learning sacred rites and providing sacrifices to the god or gods you worship. Manifestations of gods, along with their sacred works, guide you to greatness.
Bound by a deal to a powerful patron, warlocks trade their loyalty for supernatural abilities and unique magic.
Good clerics seek to better the world, empowered by their deities to heal others and destroy the undead. Selûne, Ilmater, Tyr, and Mystra are common gods they worship.
Reclusive and wise, wood elves are primarily found in the forests of Faerûn. Rigorous training makes them masters of archery and camouflage, enhanced by an otherworldly swiftness.
Evil clerics are driven to conquer and corrupt Faerûn in service to their gods. Shar, Bhaal, Bane, and Myrkul are common gods they worship.
To be half-drow is to wrestle with a violent and complicated legacy. Cleverness and tenacity serve them well, for they are caught between two very different worlds.
Small yet capable, halflings prefer the comforts of home and hearth - but their natural luck and dexterity makes them fine adventurers.
Mind flayers are aberrations that feed off brains and dominate others with pure psionic will. They create more of their own kind using tadpoles that consume a host from the inside out.
Even a generation apart, forest blood breeds true. These half-elves retain their parent's gift for speed, but tend to wander rather than staying in hidden enclaves.

Some undead seek to return to life; others long for the sweet embrace of oblivion. They move amongst the other races unseen, apex predators who can't afford detection. Lately, an unfamiliar voice beckons to them from a world unknown.
Heirs of the mystical Feywild, high elves value magic in all its forms, and even those who do not study spellcraft can manipulate the Weave.
Small yet capable, halflings prefer the comforts of home and hearth - but their natural luck and dexterity makes them fine adventurers.
Raised in an honourable - if brutally aggressive - martial culture, hobgoblins revel in the beauty of warfare. They also try to keep an iron boot on their chaotic goblinoid cousins.
A tome of necromancy has seared strange, profane glyphs into your mind, but you cannot understand them.
A tome of necromancy has seared strange, profane glyphs into your mind, but you cannot understand them.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
Helm, the Vigilant One, is the god of those who guard and defend others. His paladins are steadfast protectors, holding the line against impossible odds no matter the cost.
Fuelled by the Oath they swore to uphold justice and righteousness, most paladins are a beacon of hope in dark times.
An enthusiastic adventurer of remarkable spirit and mettle.
This corpse has been the target of a Speak with Dead spell.
Oghma is the god of knowledge. His paladins go on dangerous quests to restore lost lore, and put their lives on the line to protect strongholds of knowledge like Oghma's libraries.
Your previous oath was one of Ancients.
Heirs of the mystical Feywild, high elves value magic in all its forms, and even those who do not study spellcraft can manipulate the Weave.
Wealth and power define the nobility, but some families fare more successfully than others. A good name goes far, though.
A life spent in seclusion grants a clear mind, but makes the chaos of society distasteful.
Identifies traps as organic, so they can go "squish" and otherwise not behave like mechanical ones.
Yondalla is the mother-goddess of the halflings. Her clerics view her as a strong and protective parent who bestows them with luck, and whose example should be followed.
Descended from devils of the Nine Hells - by blood or curse - tieflings face constant suspicion in Faerûn. Their arcane abilities make them natural survivors, whether as heroes or villains.
Your previous oath was of the Devotion.

Survivors of Lolth's treachery against Corellon Larethian, Seldarine drow live in a scattered collection of Underdark city-states, warring with each other as often as the Spider Queen's cult. Many of these drow travel to the surface in search of aid, seeking to reunite their shattered people at any cost.
A step further from the Feywild than their high elf parent, these half-elves still hold a magical spark. They mature faster than their brethren, but only live a few decades longer than humans.
Ilmater is the god of suffering and endurance. His paladins are martyrs in the truest sense, taking on the burdens of the oppressed until their last breath.
Cleaving arcane magic to musical artistry, bards are performers without compare. They draw on songs empowered by spells, inspiring their allies and toppling their enemies.
Bane is the god of hatred, fear, and tyranny. His clerics are spartan, ruthless conquerors, gathering as much power as they can under Bane's banner.
Unable to speak, by nature or by magic.
Descended from the archdevil Mephistopheles, these tieflings are gifted with a particular affinity for arcane magic.
Lolth is the evil drow goddess of deceit, shadows, and spiders. Her clerics execute the will of the Spider Queen, weaving a complicated web of schemes and treachery.
Moradin, father of the dwarves, is the god of creation, smithing, stonework and protection. His paladins are champions and guardians, leading the charge against age-old dwarven enemies.
With this spell, one can read the thoughts of certain creatures.
A member of the lawful evil fiends that hail from Baator.
A servant of mind flayers that feeds on the intelligence of sentient beings.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.

With a ruthlessness borne from mind flayer enslavement, githyanki ride the Astral Sea atop red dragons, bringing their silver swords and psionic might to bear against any trace of the illithid menace.
The strong embrace the wild that hides inside - keen instincts, primal physicality, and most of all, an unbridled, unquenchable rage.
Good paladins are bastions of heroism, willing to make any sacrifice to honour their Oath and their quest. Their abilities are gifted by gods like Tyr, Selûne, Ilmater, and Mystra.
Small, clever, and energetic, gnomes use their centuries-long lifespans to explore and invent in Faerûn's brightest corners and darkest depths.
The Watchful Protector is the king of gnomish gods - a deity of humour, gem-cutting, protection, and trickery.

The elves of the Underdark, drow have been fighting a massive civil war since the goddess Lolth severed herself from the elvish pantheon, a betrayal scarring every generation that followed. Drow city-states struggle with one another for dominance, but the true war is between the cultists who serve Lolth and those who resist the goddess' corruption.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
Druids channel the elemental forces of nature and share a deep kinship with animals. Mastery of Wild Shape allows them to transform into beasts from all over the Realms.
Following the ideal of the knight in shining armour, you act with honour and virtue in the pursuit of the greater good.
Laduguer is the patron of the duergar and god of self-reliance, defence, and survival. His clerics honour him by acquiring more power and wealth through any means possible.
An enthusiastic adventurer of remarkable spirit and mettle.
The duergar - grey dwarves - were once enslaved by the eldritch mind flayer race, and adapted to freedom with grim cruelty. Their stealth and viciousness makes them feared throughout the Underdark.
A source of illumination and divination.
Eilistraee is the drow goddess of song, beauty, swordwork, hunting, and moonlight. As the patron of drow who reject the evils of their society, she instructs her clerics to offer light and hope.
Small, clever, and energetic, gnomes use their centuries-long lifespans to explore and invent in Faerûn's brightest corners and darkest depths.
While more guarded than surface gnomes, deep gnomes are known for their loyalty and cunning. Their darkvision and training in stealth keep them alive in the hostile Underdark.
Neutral paladins stand as archetypes of balance and justice, defending the world against extremes. Their quests are consecrated by deities like Helm, Kelemvor, Oghma, and Tempus.

Vlaakith, the dread lich queen of the githyanki, demands and receives utter obedience from her subjects. For clerics, their faith in their revered queen is so strong that it manifests as clerical magic.
Wizards master the arcane by specialising in individual schools of magic, combining ancient spells with modern research.
Mountain dwarves thrive in rugged terrain, standing taller than their hill dwarf cousins. Their kingdoms are a bastion of strength in northern Faerûn.
Half-elves inherit blessings from both their parents, but at the price of never quite fitting in. Curious, ambitious, and versatile, half-elves are welcome everywhere - yet struggle to stay for long.
Kylin, A servant of Tymora, Goddess of Good Fortune
Legends say dwarven blood gave stronghearts their hardiness. Resistant to poison and wellsprings of endurance, these halflings easily hold their own.
Bane is the god of hatred, fear, and tyranny. His paladins are often remorseless commanders, leading armies dedicated to crushing the weak.
You have broken your sacred Oaths in pursuit of power and ambition. Only darkness remains to fuel you now.
Corellon Larethian, ever-changing creator of all elves, is both chaos and beauty personified. Their clerics are self-reliant and find a connection to their god by truly getting to know themselves.
Descended from the archdevil Mephistopheles, these tieflings are gifted with a particular affinity for arcane magic.
To be half-drow is to wrestle with a violent and complicated legacy. Cleverness and tenacity serve them well, for they are caught between two very different worlds.
Fela, A servant of Mielikki, Goddess of forests and patron of nature.
Being implanted with a mind flayer tadpole is a fate worse than death. Isn't it?
Bhaal is the god of murder. His paladins kill not only to please him, but as a sacred act that deepens Bhaal's influence on the world.
This sorcerer's powers come from ancient forces of chaos. They churn within - waiting to burst free at any time.
Laduguer is the patron of the duergar. His paladins are grim warriors who act as spearheads in the fight against the many dangerous forces of the Underdark.
Half-elves inherit blessings from both their parents, but at the price of never quite fitting in. Curious, ambitious, and versatile, half-elves are welcome everywhere - yet struggle to stay for long.
With an ethereal countenance and long lifespans, elves are at home with nature and its power. Flourishing in light and darkness alike, an elf can be beautiful and terrifying in equal measure.
Lolth is the evil drow goddess of deceit, shadows, and spiders. While paladins of Lolth are rare, she sometimes bestows a gifted devotee with extra powers, drawing out an untapped potential.
Selûne is the goddess of the moon, and her paladins are soldiers in the constant war against her dark sister Shar. They use her light to dispel darkness and relieve the pain of others.
One of the more common creatures to see in Faerûn, primarily defined as standing on two feet while being neither undead nor monstrous.
Shar is the goddess of darkness, loss, and secrets. Her paladins steal forbidden knowledge, poison the blessings of other gods, and murder those who serve Selûne without a hint of remorse.

Shar is the goddess of darkness, secrets, and loss. Forever in conflict with her twin sister Selûne, Shar's clerics poison the world with fear and suffering while stealing forbidden knowledge in her name.
Even smaller than their cousins and twice as reclusive, forest gnomes are a rare sight in Faerûn. They master magic and craftsmanship in their distant, idyllic groves.
Corellon Larethian, ever-changing creator of all elves. His paladins are protectors of all things beautiful and champions in the never-ending fight against the enemies of the elves.
Oghma is the Lord of Knowledge, overseeing inspiration and invention. His clerics spread truth, encourage innovation, and stamp out falsehoods wherever they go.

Kelemvor is the fair-minded judge of the dead, shepherding lost souls to the afterlife. His clerics perform burial rites and punish those who unnaturally extend their lifespans, such as liches and vampires.
Mountain dwarves thrive in rugged terrain, standing taller than their hill dwarf cousins. Their kingdoms are a bastion of strength in northern Faerûn.
This entity has been polymorphed into a delicious and presumably very perplexed cheese.
Garl Glittergold is the king of gnomish gods, a deity of humour, gem-cutting, protection, and trickery. His clerics are often artisans or storytellers, relaying his tenets to the younger generations.
Formally trained in a militia or army, soldiers know tactics and combat like the back of their hand.
Selûne is the goddess of the moon, navigation, and lycanthropes. Her clerics honour Selûne's empathy and mystique, but are fearsome when facing Selûne's wicked sister, the goddess Shar.

The elves of the Underdark, drow have been fighting a massive civil war since the goddess Lolth severed herself from the elvish pantheon, a betrayal scarring every generation that followed. Drow city-states struggle with one another for dominance, but the true war is between the cultists who serve Lolth and those who resist the goddess' corruption.

Your skill in a particular craft has earned you membership in a mercantile guild, offering privileges and protection while engaging in your art. Discovering rare components for wondrous crafts will provide the perfect muse.
Neutral clerics uphold ideals of balance, fairness, and impartiality to further their faith. Helm, Kelemvor, Oghma, and Tempus are common gods they worship.
Evil paladins are merciless tyrants, willing to destroy whatever gets in their way. They swear Oaths to gods like Shar, Bhaal, Bane, and Myrkul.
Well-read and vigorous studies, sages always seek knowledge, often trading their own expertise for that of others.
Standing a head below most of Faerûn can be boon or bane, depending on whom one meets.
Monks use discipline and ritual to harness the energy inside their bodies, transforming it into explosive power. They excel at unarmed combat, for their defence is as strong as their spirit.
Named for their inclination to stealth, lightfoot halflings are nonetheless happy in the spotlight. They enjoy travel, and many have made names for themselves across Faerûn.
Myrkul is the god of death and decay. He has few clerics, but those who serve his faith inspire a fear of death in others, bringing doom wherever they tread.

Survivors of Lolth's treachery against Corellon Larethian, Seldarine drow live in a scattered collection of Underdark city-states, warring with each other as often as the Spider Queen's cult. Many of these drow travel to the surface in search of aid, seeking to reunite their shattered people at any cost.

The duergar - grey dwarves - were once enslaved by the eldritch mind flayer race, and adapted to freedom with a remarkably grim cruelty. Their stealth and viciousness makes them feared throughout the Underdark.
Rock gnomes are the most common to see on Faerûn's surface, named as such for their hardiness and affinity for metal.
As unparalleled scouts, rangers are in tune with the world around them, no matter how strange the terrain. They excel at hunting their favoured prey, tracking them without rest or relief.
Rock gnomes are the most common to see on Faerûn's surface, named as such for their hardiness and affinity for metal.
Bound to Nessus, the deepest layer of the Hells, these tieflings inherit the ability to wield fire and darkness from the archdevil Asmodeus' infernal bloodline.
Tieflings from Zariel's bloodline are empowered with martial strength, and can channel searing flame to punish their enemies.
Violence is both a means and an end. You follow a path of untrammelled fury, slick with blood, as you thrill in the chaos of battle, heedless of your own well-being.
With stealth, skill, and uncanny reflexes, rogues' versatility lets them get the upper hand in almost any situation.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
The most common face to see in Faerûn, humans often face stiff competition from long-lived races, but hold their own with tenacity, creativity, and an endless capacity for growth.
Kelemvor is the judge of the dead. His paladins take on quests to destroy powerful undead, for their very existence subverts Kelemvor's will.
Legends say dwarven blood gave stronghearts their hardiness. Resistant to poison and wellsprings of endurance, these halflings easily hold their own.

Raised in one of Lolth's massive cults spread throughout the Underdark, these drow extol the virtues of their corrupt and merciless goddess, seeking to bring all other drow under her sway. Lolth marks her followers with vivid red eyes, in hope every race in Faerûn will learn to fear the very sight of them.
Bound to Nessus, the deepest layer of the Hells, these tieflings inherit the ability to wield fire and darkness from the archdevil Asmodeus' infernal bloodline.
Even smaller than their cousins and twice as reclusive, forest gnomes are a rare sight in Faerûn. They master magic and craftsmanship in their distant, idyllic groves.
Named for their inclination to stealth, lightfoot halflings are nonetheless happy in the spotlight. They enjoy travel, and many have made names for themselves across Faerûn.
Tyr is the god of justice, and his paladins are the sword that enforces this justice. They constantly hunt monsters and other wicked beings, for none may escape the Maimed God's sight.
A connoisseur of deals that are too good to be true. Prone to exaggeration, and more than happy to profit from it.

With a ruthlessness borne from mind flayer enslavement, githyanki ride the Astral Sea atop red dragons, bringing their silver swords and psionic might to bear against any trace of the illithid menace.
A step further from the Feywild than their high elf parent, these half-elves still hold a magical spark. They mature faster than their brethren, but only live a few decades longer than humans.
Descended from devils of the Nine Hells - by blood or curse - tieflings face constant suspicion in Faerûn. Their arcane abilities make them natural survivors, whether as heroes or villains.
Mystra is the goddess of all magic, guarding the Weave that allows mortal spellcasters to access its power. Her clerics preserve ancient lore and protect bastions of magic.
Eilistraee is a drow god of moonlight, song, swordwork and dance. Her paladins are tasked with coaxing other drow away from evil, and hunting the demonic agents of Lolth.
Durable and unyielding as their homes of stone, dwarves are some of the finest warriors, miners, and smiths of Faerûn.
Being raised in the Underdark casts a cruel shadow on one's view of the world, even up on the surface.

Bhaal is the notorious god of murder. He once spread his heritage and sadistic impulses through all of Faerûn, then resurrected himself in a horrific ritual. His clerics are assassins, deliberately killing to honour their god.
This sorcerer's veins carry draconic magic, the result of a powerful dragon ancestor.
Vlaakith is the dread lich queen of the githyanki. Anointed in a dark ritual, her paladins are chosen warriors who obey her every command.
Your patron is a mysterious entity whose nature is utterly foreign to the fabric of reality.
Hill dwarves are defined by their keen intuition and heightened senses. Their resilience has kept a massive kingdom in the south intact for centuries.
After surviving a childhood on the streets, you know how to make the most out of very little. Helping youth in need bolsters your spirit for the journey ahead.
Tyr is the god of law and justice, and encourages his clerics to uphold them no matter the sacrifices that must be made. He grants spells that enhance accuracy and martial prowess.

Moradin, the All-Father, is the god of the dwarf people, as well as the god of creation, smithing, stonework, and protection. His clerics guide the morals of dwarven communities and lead the charge against those who would assault them.
Committed to preserving life, you fight on the side of the light in the cosmic struggle against darkness.
To live is to perform, and entertainers know that best. Hard-earned skill with acrobatics and instruments is key when appealing to the masses.
Magic brews in a sorcerer's blood. By channelling natural talent into powerful spells, a sorcerer is born to arcane greatness.
A member of the chaotic evil fiends native to the Abyss.
You have made a pact with a fiend from the Lower Planes of existence, a being whose aims are evil, even if you strive against those aims.
Yondalla is the mother-goddess of the halflings. Following her example, her paladins devote their lives to protecting their communities.
A servant of the god of morning dawn, whose deific name is Lathander.
Eryn, A servant of Talos, God of Storms
You are pushed by greed and wanderlust, ever curious, seeking hoards and wonders unknown. Finding secret treasures opens the path to new discoveries.
Helm, the Vigilant One, is the god of those guard and defend others. His clerics serve as implacable sentries, often wearing heavy plate armour to emulate their deity.
Eilistraee is the goddess of good-aligned drow, beauty, song, and freedom. The Dark Maiden seeks to reconcile the ancient conflict between her people and those who live on Faerûn's surface.
Hill dwarves are defined by their keen intuition and heightened senses. Their resilience has kept a massive kingdom in the south intact for centuries.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
The famed Blade of Frontiers, the pride of Baldur's Gate.
A charmer and a rake with the most dangerous smile in Baldur's Gate.
For exposing Kagha's corruption, you have been honoured by the druids as a defender of nature and balance.

A servant of the five-headed queen of dragons, Tiamat.
While not true dragons themselves, draconic lineage defines the dragonborn. They inherit powerful breath weapons from their ancestors and possess a preternatural toughness.
Venji, A servant of Mielikki, Goddess of forests and patron of nature.
Kulishov, A servant of Tymora, Goddess of Good Fortune

Although they descend from cultures of strength and martial prowess, most half-orcs are born in times of peace. Whenever orcish wars end, alliances and marriages lead to a new generation of shared blood.
While not true dragons themselves, draconic lineage defines the dragonborn. They inherit powerful breath weapons from their ancestors and possess a preternatural toughness.
Casting aside even your own purity, you deliver justice to those who have committed the most grievous sins.

When a feckless amateur spellcaster attempts to create life, and bungles it, the result is a Gremishka. Spiteful, malformed, and hideously feline, Gremishka's hold a particular loathing for practitioners of the arcane arts, a dark reflection of typical parental love.
A servant of Bahamut, God of metallic dragons.
A servant of the five-headed queen of dragons, Tiamat.
Enro, A servant of Lathander, God of the dawn.
Kosen, A servant of Talos, God of Storms
Deva, an Angel in Service to a God
A servant of Bahamut, god of metallic dragons.
Olov, Cleric of Gruumsh, God of Conquest
Sim, A servant of Gruumsh One-Eye, God of Conquest and patron of orcs.

Long before Karsus cast the spell that would seal the fate of Netheril Human empire, were emerging the fundations of Thultanthar, the City of Shade, an entiere city casted into the Astral Plane of Shadow. Fighting their way against Shadows and other aberrations made of pure shadows, these humans survived over many centuries and sharpened an absolute and unconditionnal faith in Shar.
For over 1500 years they attuned to the plane itself, soaking the shadows in their essences. When they finally find a way out of the Shadow Plane, it was only to discover the ruin of a fallen empire.

They were most of what remains of Netheril empire. Often hidden deep beneath the ground, where Shar keeps her secrets, these very first Voidborns are mostly unknowns, but some legends refer to theim as Shadovars.

Oathsworn Hands of Shar abide by the following tenets:

Love shall perish. « Love is the cruellest of all the lies used by Our Lady of Loss foes. It is a disease - one that can ensnare hearts for a lifetime over something as slight as a passing glimpse. »

Hide her secrets in Darkness. « Our Lady of Loss knows what pains you, and gnaws away at your very being. Be open with her about your failings. Let her place the soothing hands of oblivion upon your wounds. Let her know you utterly, so she can release you from your shackles. »

Blow out the Candles. « Light was a mistake, and life is an illusion - a discordant song composed of lies, breaking the peace of oblivion. »

Erase Life. « Emptiness is a holy state - one to be pursued and admired. To void oneself of all feeling, all attachment, is to approach the purity of Lady Shar's embrace. » ----Church of Shar holy scriptures.
Failure to abide by their tenets will result in something really bad.

Shar's cursed touch is feared by many entities across the cosmos for its ability to curse even the land itself. Chose a secret to be stolen.

Auril, The Frostmaiden :
Auril was known for her relentless drive to completely freeze entire lands, siphoning all forms of energy and leaving behind nothing but a mass of atoms in the purest state of energetic void. Such power will inevitably draw the attention of Our Lady of Loss, who will claim it for herself, twisting it into a form of Shadow Curse.

Myrkul, Lord of the Dead :
Once a mortal necromancer, Myrkul realized that achieving divinity required deicide. He pursued and ultimately slew Maram, a primordial elemental of chaos, claiming divine power for himself. Now known as « Myrkul, Lord of Bones », he gained the ability to spread plagues, cursing even the very soil of cemeteries. With the power to manipulate life and death at will, he attracted countless followers, priests, and pilgrims.
Gain Resistance to Necrotic damage, taking only half damage from it.

Shar's cursed touch is feared by many entities across the cosmos for its ability to curse even the land itself.

Auril was known for her relentless drive to completely freeze entire lands, siphoning all forms of energy and leaving behind nothing but a mass of atoms in the purest state of energetic void. Such power will inevitably draw the attention of Our Lady of Loss, who will claim it for herself, twisting it into a form of Shadow Curse.

Once a mortal necromancer, Myrkul realized that achieving divinity required deicide. He pursued and ultimately slew Maram, a primordial elemental of chaos, claiming divine power for himself. Now known as « Myrkul, Lord of Bones », he gained the ability to spread plagues, cursing even the very soil of cemeteries. With the power to manipulate life and death at will, he attracted countless followers, priests, and pilgrims.

Shar, the Nightbringer

« According to one of the most ancient myths of the creation of the world and the heavens, after the universe and its crystal sphere were created by Lord Ao, there was naught but the primordial essence, the protoplasmic raw stuff of existence. Described as chaos and timeless nothingness, the sphere was filled with no more than dim misty shadows, neither light nor dark, for such things had not yet separated. All that moved here were the shadevari, the thirteen lords of shadow, whose origin, whether from elsewhere or from the shadow itself, is unknown. In time, Shar coalesced from the primordial essence, alongside her twin sister, Selûne. » ----Ancient tomes of the Forgotten Realms.

The Unseen Lady thrives on forbidden knowledge stolen from other deities. Here is the list of her forbidden knowledge stolen.
Myrkul, also known as the Lord of Bones, is the God of Death and a member of the Dead Three. He is associated with the domain of Death.

Auril, the Queen of Frozen Tears, personifies the merciless chill of winter and its most lethal aspects. Her icy beauty, as cold as her heart, is eternally preserved beneath a veil of frost, embodying the cruel and unrelenting force of the frozen season.
Myrkul, also known as the Lord of Bones, is the God of Death and a member of the Dead Three. He is associated with the domain of Death.

Auril is the goddess of cold and winter, a Neutral Evil deity who commands her paladins to wield icy weapons and freeze their foes in battle. She empowers them to deliver devastating strikes infused with frost and unrelenting cold.
Auril is the goddess of cold and winter, a Neutral Evil deity who urges her clerics to raise ice and freeze all in their path. She grants spells that unleash devastating storms of frost and ice.

Auril, the Queen of Frozen Tears, personifies the merciless chill of winter and its most lethal aspects. Her icy beauty, as cold as her heart, is eternally preserved beneath a veil of frost, embodying the cruel and unrelenting force of the frozen season.
As the greater deity of darkness, Shar is feared for her power over the night, secrets, and loss. She is locked in eternal conflict with her twin sister Selûne, goddess of the moon.
The Lady of Silver presides over the moon, stars, and navigation. Her power over the heavens is constantly challenged by her sister Shar, who seeks to plunge the world into eternal shadow.

Shar’s dominion grows deeper within you, her whispers twisting reality to serve her will. The shadows tremble as her secrets are unveiled, granting you the power to shape the battlefield and sow despair. Choose a secret to shape your path.

Auril's Eternal Frost :
Auril’s unyielding frost settles over your soul, a shard of eternal winter that empowers you to halt even the most unrelenting adversaries. Her icy touch grips the land, encasing it in lifeless stillness and freezing hope itself. The Frostmaiden’s blessing is as beautiful as it is deadly, ensuring that no foe escapes the creeping chill of her domain. With every step, you carry the essence of winter's wrath, spreading desolation wherever you tread.

Myrkul's Decaying Grasp :
Myrkul’s power seeps into your strikes, the cold embrace of death creeping through your veins. Each blow spreads the touch of decay, rotting life to its core and leaving only silence and stillness in its wake. As the Lord of Bones grants you his grasp, the fragile spark of life falters before the inevitability of death. In his name, you become a harbinger of endings, and the whispers of the grave follow your every move, devouring the living with quiet inevitability.

The Mistress of Night grants you forbidden power, stolen from realms untold. Choose how her shadow reshapes your destiny.

Auril's Frozen Aegis :
The Stormbringer's fury echoes the desolation of Shar’s eternal night. In the ancient days, when the cold winds howled across lifeless tundras, it is said that Auril sought the Mistress of Night’s blessing, hoping to wield the darkness that lies within the void of winter. Now, her Frozen Aegis shields you from harm, encasing you in unyielding frost. Those who dare strike you are met with the biting chill of her vengeance, their very movements frozen by the wrath of the Frostmaiden. With her power, the winter follows your every step, leaving behind a trail of ice and despair.

Myrkul's Necrotic Legacy :
The Lord of Bones, Myrkul, whispers of secrets stolen from the halls of death itself. Once, when Shar sought to shape her shadowed realm, Myrkul offered her the silence of the grave in return for power unending. His Necrotic Legacy now imbues your strikes, binding the souls of the fallen to your will. Those who perish before you rise again, hollowed by death, their will broken and their strength forever yours. With every step, you spread his dominion, and the silence of the grave follows in your wake, as the whispers of Shar and Myrkul entwine to reshape the destiny of mortals.
%%% Very similar to Frost Shield, prototype : Symbotic

A pact forged in shadows lets you <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_Hide_Vanish">Vanish</LSTag> instantly, concealing yourself in darkness. Striking from the gloom <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BLINDED">blinds</LSTag> or <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="MADNESS">confuses</LSTag> your foes.

Cyric’s whispers cloud your mind with promises of power and deception. Hidden in the shadows, your strikes carry the chaos of his treachery. When attacking while <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="SNEAKING">stealthed</LSTag> or <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="INVISIBLE">invisible</LSTag>, your attacks inflict an additional [1], with another [1] added against targets that are <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BLINDED">blinded</LSTag> or <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BLEEDING">bleeding</LSTag>.

The Seductress's insatiable hunger for power twists the gifts of other deities into tools of shadow and deception. Her stolen secrets are tainted with treachery and cruelty, offering a dark path to those who dare claim them. Choose how her forbidden whispers will shape your next step.

Zehir's Venomous Whisper :
The god of poison and shadows, Zehir, grants you the deadly precision of a serpent. His venomous whispers guide your strikes, leaving behind wounds that fester and spread his corruption. Those who dare cross your path fall prey to the slow, agonizing decay of his touch. Zehir’s blessing is not just a gift, but a curse, binding you to his shadowed path of fear and death. In his name, you strike swiftly and lethally, like the serpent coiled in darkness, ready to deliver its fatal bite.

Cyric's Treacherous Pact :
Cyric, the Prince of Lies and Deception, weaves his influence deep into your soul, filling your mind with promises of unmatched power. His pact grants you the ability to manipulate the battlefield, turning enemies against each other and leaving chaos in your wake. Those ensnared by his treachery are blinded by confusion, unable to discern friend from foe. But Cyric’s gifts come with a price: the deeper you delve into his lies, the more your own reality twists and fractures. His blessing ensures that nothing, not even the truth, will ever be as it seems.

The Nightsinger’s dominion grows ever deeper, her tapestry of shadows entangling even the mightiest deities. From her domain atop the Towers of Night, she wove alliances with gods of poison and deceit, twisting their gifts to serve her designs. Choose how her stolen secrets will reshape your path.

Zehir’s Shadowed Fangs :
The Master of Poisons and Shadows shared his venom with Shar in the earliest days of the Shadowfell. From his dark sanctum within the Towers of Night, his coils spread death and fear across the planes. His venom now courses through your veins, granting you the lethal cunning of the serpent. Each strike delivers his toxic wrath, breaking the will of your foes and leaving only despair in your wake. Like Zehir himself, you become a living shadow of fear and inevitability.

Cyric’s Web of Lies :
The Dark Prince, the god of lies and deception, forever etched his name into history when he struck down Mystra, unraveling the Weave and plunging the realms into chaos. With Shar’s guidance, he shattered not only the fabric of magic but also the minds of countless mortals. His treachery now fuels your strikes, sowing madness and confusion in your enemies. Those who cross you are blinded by falsehoods, ensnared by illusions, and undone by their own doubts. In Cyric’s name, the truth becomes your weapon, and deception your greatest ally.

The God of Thieves steals even the most sacred gifts, twisting them into instruments of shadow and despair. Her dominion over the Towers of Night allowed her to forge pacts with deities of poison and deceit, channeling their powers into forbidden secrets. Now, her ultimate gifts await you. Choose which stolen secret will crown your journey.

Zehir’s Venomous Domain :
Zehir once ruled alongside Shar within the Towers of Night, his toxic influence seeping into the very foundations of the Shadowfell. His dominion over venom deepens within you, granting unmatched resistance to toxins and empowering your strikes with the potency of his deadly wrath. With every blow, the serpent’s venom courses through your enemies, paralyzing their will and spreading despair in their ranks. You become the embodiment of his corruption, a shadow of poison that strikes without mercy.

Cyric’s Madness Unleashed :
The Dark Sun brought chaos to the planes when he struck down Mystra with Shar’s guidance, unraveling the Weave and sending ripples of madness across the realms. Now, his touch shatters the minds of those who stand against you. Your presence alone is a weapon, instilling confusion, despair, and paranoia in all who cross your path. Those caught within your grasp see their reality crumble, leaving them powerless to resist. Cyric’s blessing crowns you as an agent of chaos, a puppet master of madness and deception.

Zehir is the god of poison and shadows, a Chaotic Evil deity who commands his clerics to spread venom and sow chaos. He grants spells that envenom weapons and summon deadly serpents to strike from the dark.

Zehir is the god of poison and shadows, a Chaotic Evil deity who empowers his paladins to wield venomous weapons and strike swiftly from the darkness. He grants abilities to envenom their blades and spread death with every blow.
Zehir, the god of poison and shadows, is a cunning interloper who carved his domain in a realm of toxic mists and perpetual night. His venomous will seeps into Toril, spreading corruption and death.

Cyric, the Prince of Lies, is the god of strife, trickery, and illusion. Once a tyrant who sought to unravel the divine order, his murder of Mystra and alliance with Shar plunged the cosmos into chaos during the Spellplague. His shadow lingers still, drawing mortals into discord and deceit, promising power but delivering only ruin.
Zehir, the god of poison and shadows, is a cunning interloper who carved his domain in a realm of toxic mists and perpetual night. His venomous will seeps into Toril, spreading corruption and death.

Cyric is the god of lies and strife, a Chaotic Evil deity who urges his clerics to sow discord and manipulate the weak. He grants spells that deceive, confound, and twist the minds of those who oppose them.

Cyric is the god of lies and strife, a Chaotic Evil deity who commands his paladins to wield deception as their greatest weapon. He empowers them to strike from the shadows, spreading chaos and despair with every calculated blow.

Sworn servants of Shar, the Singer of Eternal Night, Nightcloaks act as shadowy agents of her will. They move unseen, hiding forbidden knowledge, hunting her enemies, and spreading her influence through manipulation and fear. Using the Shadow Weave, a remnant of Netheril’s ancient magic, Nightcloaks command shadows and bend reality to serve Shar’s vision of eternal darkness. Charismatic and cunning, they excel at turning allies into tools and foes into whispers of the past.
